column1: Ronda Douglas is a 52 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit.

Patient last seen October 2024. She has a.m. nausea vomiting. She has been on omeprazole at supper and famotidine at bedtime but has had no improvement. She has episodes of a.m. nausea vomiting every 2 to 3 months. We talked about Ozempic and she tells me she has been off of that as long as 6 months and that has not helped. She has had a gastric emptying study that was normal. Patient has never been on Voquezna.

She also tells me that she has episodes of fecal incontinence at night. Patient had a colonoscopy in October 24. She had mild grade 1 internal hemorrhoids but no other findings. I have suggested we try the new medication.

column2: Adhere to lifestyle and dietary modifications for GERD diet as we discussed. This includes avoiding fatty and greasy foods, fried foods, tomato based foods, caffeine, carbonated drinks, coffee and alcohol. Elevate the head of your bed 6 inches. Additionally, do not eat or drink anything including water within two hours of going to bed at night or 10pm, whichever comes first. Recommend low fat, low cholesterol diet and exercise.

1) Consume 20–25 grams of fiber daily. Consider adding a fiber supplement such as Benefiber, Konsyl, Citrucel, Metamucil, ground flax seed, ground chia seed, etc. Take 1 teaspoon by mouth daily for 5–7 days, then 2 teaspoons by mouth daily for 5–7 days, then 1 tablespoon by mouth daily. 2) Consume at least 64 ounces of water daily. Increase water intake as needed for exercise and other water losses. 3) Minimize caffeine and alcohol. 4) Exercise on a regular basis as tolerated If adding a fiber

column1: Janet (Jill) Worden is a 76 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit.

Initial visit 1/23/25. She was previously seen by Dr. Faruqi, records reviewed, followed for tubular adenomas and 1 SSL on colonoscopy 9/24/21. Presents with heartburn and constipation. Weight loss from 138 lbs to 104.6 lbs. Followed by Jackie. Accompanied today by niece Becky who is from Washington. History of COPD   Heartburn tends to get better with PO intake. Typically has constipation, but has recently started bran, bananas, avocado which helps with her constipation. Reports lower abdominal bloating.  Reports claustrophobia. Lives alone since her husband passed, often times experiences anxiety. Most of her family live around Cypress.

Visit 2/27/25: Records reviewed,  Abd US 11/16/23 with 1cm R renal cyst, otherwise normal. Memorial Herman ER visit 7/7/24 with leukocytosis (10.97), left shift, normal LFTs, CT abd/pelvis with renal cysts, otherwise no acute findings. Has been eating a bowl of bran and avocadoes daily with improvement in constipation. Trying to eat more. Gained 1 lb since last visit. Was given an antibiotic for lung issues. Tried pepcid without improvement of symptoms.

Visit 3/27/25: Took pantoprazole 20mg daily in the morning, with symptoms in the afternoon but can happen all throughout the day.. Has been taking bran and avocado for fiber and feels full eating and constipation is improved in addition to taking colace TID. Still smoking. Following up with opthalmologist as well as other doctors

Visit 5/22/25: Reports pantoprazole 20mg BID with unclear improvement. Symptoms still occur every other day. Trying to  quit smoking. Reports previous poor experience with pill based form of prep. Reports intermittent palpitations, reports cardiology wants to consider ablation. Worried about procedural risks. Concerned about beta blockers interaction with COPD medications. Friends with Terry and Marsha Edge.

Visit 7/11/25: Started having firm stools in June, had worsening loose BMs with laxatives, mg citrate. Started miralax today. Started increasing fiber intake, avocados Has been drinking lots of water with Liquid IV, having clear urine. Lost 2 lbs of weight in the past 2 months.

Visit 8/7/25:  CT chest/abd/pelvis 7/24/25 with severe centrilobular emphysema, mod CAD, severe aortic calcification, anterolisthesis of L3/L4  Tried Ibsrela dose and experienced diarrhea. Had been taking avocado daily. Accompanied by her friend.

Visit 9/10/25: Has doubled Metamucil to 1 Tbsp BID, on 9/5, with BMs now twice a day. Has quit smoking with onset of weight gain. Peripheral edema when standing when chopping in the kitchen. Stools are spiral in nature. Discussed consideration for colonoscopy with decision to defer

Jill Floyd is a 49-year-old female with a past medical history of GERD, asthma, multiple sclerosis, sleep apnea, hypertension, and endometriosis who presents for evaluation of new onset dysphagia, early satiety, and shortness of breath. She was previously evaluated in May 2025 for vomiting, thought to be secondary to Wegovy use, which has since resolved after discontinuing the medication.
Esophagram on 05/12/2025 noted mild esophageal dysmotility.

EGD on 05/19/2025 noted a normal esophagus, mild antral erythema, and normal duodenum. Esophageal biopsies were consistent with reflux esophagitis with no evidence of Barrett's esophagus or eosinophilic esophagitis. Gastric biopsies were negative for H. pylori.

The primary concern is new-onset dysphagia to solids and pills, along with early satiety and associated shortness of breath, which began approximately one week ago. She reports a sensation of food and pills becoming lodged in the chest, which is a new symptom not present during her evaluation in May. This is associated with a feeling of fullness after only a few bites of food, which then provokes shortness of breath. She denies regurgitation of food. She also reports a recent increase in eructation. No significant reflux. She recently stopped taking omeprazole two days ago at the direction of her nephrologist and was advised by her asthma provider to taper off it using over-the-counter Pepcid on alternate days.

She also reports a new onset of significant lower extremity edema, abdominal distention, and exertional dyspnea over the last week. She was seen by her nephrologist for new abnormal kidney function labs from July and August 2025, consistent with stage 3 kidney disease. She was started on HCTZ two days ago with a 6-pound weight loss since yesterday. She denies any known liver disease or cardiac history. She is scheduled for a renal ultrasound, lower extremity ultrasound, and chest x-ray today.

column1: Dysphagia and early satiety: New symptoms in the setting of known mild esophageal dysmotility and reflux esophagitis noted on prior evaluation in May. However, at that time her primary concern was vomiting, which has now resolved. She was not having dysphagia at the time of her esophagram and EGD. The workup for her significant fluid overload and acute kidney injury should take precedence.
- Repeat barium esophagram with 13-mm tablet to evaluate for any new structural abnormality or worsening dysmotility.
- Will defer repeat EGD at this time given active work up underway for new diagnosis of renal dysfunction and anasarca

- If esophagram is unrevealing and symptoms persist after other medical issues are clarified, may need Repeat EGD for more extensive biopsies or referral to Baylor esophageal center for dysmotility evaluation.
- Advised to taper omeprazole as suggested by her other provider and use Pepcid as an alternative.
Reflux esophagitis: History of reflux esophagitis on biopsy. No significant GERD symptoms at this time but does have increased belching
- Continue plan to taper omeprazole per the advice of her nephrologist and use Pepcid as an alternative for symptom management.
Abnormal kidney function and anasarca: Currently being evaluated by nephrology.
- Await results of renal ultrasound, lower extremity ultrasound, and chest x-ray. She will have us copied on the results.
- If she has evidence of ascites may need to consider additional evaluation for any underlying cardiac or liver dysfunction (per her report she believes recent labs showed normal liver enzymes)
- Continue HCTZ as prescribed by nephrology.
Follow-up will be pending review of the esophagram
Call office with any questions or concerns.

column1: 73-year-old male referred for difficulty swallowing by Brandi Gosdin, PA. Known to me from evaluation in 2021 when he was referred for colonoscopy. Last visit was in 2021.

This 73-year-old gentleman presents for evaluation of dysphagia. He reports a sensation of food getting stuck in his lower chest, which is then associated with production of saliva that he spits up. He finds that drinking milk or creamer helps the food to pass. He was prescribed omeprazole by his primary care provider, which has significantly improved his symptoms. He notes that if he forgets to take the medication for a day or two, the symptoms recur. He also reports a history of frequent heartburn and acid sensations prior to starting the medication. He denies any other reflux symptoms.

His last colonoscopy was in 2021, at which time a polyp, consistent with a sessile serrated adenoma, was removed from the ascending colon. There was also self-limited ischemic colitis noted at that time. He has remained asymptomatic from that. He was advised to return in five years for a repeat colonoscopy, which is now due in 2026. He reports having two polyps removed during that procedure, and also two polyps removed in a colonoscopy five years prior to that. He has not had a prior upper endoscopy.

Pertinent upper GI symptoms include dysphagia and a history of heartburn. He denies nausea, vomiting, bloating, or other reflux symptoms. Pertinent lower GI symptoms are negative; he denies change in bowel habits, constipation, diarrhea, blood in stool, or rectal bleeding.
GI medications include omeprazole, which he takes for his symptoms.
Past medical history is significant for asthma, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension. Past surgical history is significant for colonoscopy with polypectomy in 2021.

Social history includes working in construction. He denies use of any blood thinners. He has a family history of colon cancer in his sister. His mother also had a mass, but it was not investigated before her death.
Colonoscopy (2021): Colitis in the ascending colon. A sessile serrated adenoma was noted and removed.

column1: 1. Dysphagia: The presentation is suggestive of acid reflux-related dysphagia, given the significant improvement with omeprazole. However, given the new onset of dysphagia in a 73-year-old, an underlying structural cause, including malignancy, needs to be ruled out.
- Plan to proceed with an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) to evaluate the esophagus.

2. Colon Cancer Screening: He is due for a surveillance colonoscopy in 2026 due to a history of a sessile serrated adenoma and a family history of colon cancer. Given he requires sedation for the EGD, we discussed performing both procedures concurrently to avoid two separate preparations and sedation events.
- Plan to schedule a colonoscopy at the same time as the EGD.
- Discussed the procedure, risks, benefits, and alternatives. Stressed the need for an excellent bowel preparation.
- Your main issue is trouble swallowing. While the medicine we have you on seems to be helping, which suggests it may be related to acid reflux, we need to be sure there is no other cause.
- We will schedule you for an upper endoscopy (EGD), which is a scope to look at your esophagus and stomach.
- Since you are also due for a repeat colonoscopy next year to check for polyps, we discussed doing both procedures at the same time. This is more convenient and avoids needing sedation twice.
- My assistant, Amy, will contact you to get these procedures scheduled.
- Please continue taking your omeprazole as prescribed. It is working well for your symptoms.
- You will need to arrange for someone, such as your wife, to drive you to and from the procedure, as you will receive sedation and will not be able to drive for the rest of the day.

1. Today we discussed your upcoming procedure:
- We discussed the importance of an excellent preparation to minimize the risk of missed polyps. **Please read the instructions for the preparation one week prior to your exam.**

- Risks include sedation related risks, perforation, immediate or delayed bleeding, infection, as well as the low risk of incomplete procedure due to retained food, poor preparation, anatomy, or a large/difficult polyp, requiring a repeat. Please call if you are having pain or bleeding after a procedure.
- If you take aspirin, you may continue taking this. Please avoid all tobacco products on the day of your procedure.

- If we remove polyps or take biopsies, you can expect to hear those results in about 1-2 weeks via either letter, phone call, or portal message. Please call 972-637-8480 if you do not hear within 3 weeks.

column1: David Walker is an 81-year-old male with a past medical history of obstructive sleep apnea, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and fatty liver who presents for evaluation of a positive stool test for blood and anemia. He was last seen in this practice in 2009 for elevated liver enzymes. Reported history is a bit tangential.

Reports that he was recently seen at the VA which noted new finding of anemia. He subsequently had stool based test which was positive for blood in the stool. These records are not available for review. He is uncertain if any specific iron studies were obtained. He is presently not on iron supplementation. He denies any hematochezia, melena or any overt signs of bleeding. He does endorse a change in his bowel habits for approximately 1 year characterized by alternating patterns of constipation consisting of up to 2 days without a bowel movement. He will then subsequently have a few bowel movements the following day. Stool is formed, described as small soft pieces. He reports occasional episodes of minor fecal incontinence if stool consistency is loose. He notes mild, intermittent abdominal discomfort associated with gas. Denies nausea, vomiting, reflux. He did sustain an approximately 50 pound weight loss after having COVID-pneumonia in 2021, now believes his weight has been fairly stable. He reports occasional episodes of dysphagia to solid foods, such as chicken. Described a sensation of food becoming stuck in his upper chest/throat, usually requiring liquids to help it pass. His last colonoscopy was over 10 years ago. He denies any known cardiac or pulmonary conditions, no anticoagulants. However, he states that at some point he was to have possible Ortho surgery, however there was an unspecified concern regarding his heart. He was seen by Dr. Hussain for workup, he believes testing all returned negative but he is uncertain of details.  Denies chest pain, shortness of breath, edema.

column1: Heather Beaird is a 43-year-old female with a history of chronic idiopathic constipation, GERD, and post-hysterectomy status, presenting with ongoing, severe symptoms.

She reports persistent constipation for the past 2-4 years, requiring a combination of Linzess, lubiprostone, Miralax, and occasional Dulcolax suppositories or Prunelax to achieve a bowel movement. She aims for one bowel movement daily but often goes 2-3 days without, leading to increased discomfort. Symptoms are associated with significant bloating, nausea, vomiting, and dizziness. The nausea is unpredictable and can occur with or without food intake.

She reports a history of entering menopause at age 36. She had a post-hysterectomy appointment with her OB/GYN this morning (09/11/2025) and was found to have poor absorption of her hormone cream. She was started on an oral estradiol 5 mg pill and an increased dose of testosterone cream today. She hopes hormonal regulation may improve her GI symptoms. She has seen Dr. Hughston for these issues in the past. She also notes having a problematic internal hemorrhoid but is reluctant to undergo surgical removal due to the painful recovery.

Her last visit was on 03/07/2025 for severe upper abdominal pain, which was evaluated in the ER. A CT scan on 03/05/2025 showed no acute abnormalities. Labs were notable for a slightly elevated lipase of 87. A subsequent EGD was performed by Dr. Hughston on 03/19/2025, which showed a normal esophagus, stomach, and duodenum. Biopsies were normal with no evidence of Celiac Sprue or H. pylori.
Her last colonoscopy in August 2024 was normal except for internal hemorrhoids.
Reports: abdominal pain, bloating/gas, constipation, nausea, vomiting, fatigue.

Denies: heartburn/reflux, difficulty swallowing, anorectal pain/itching, blood in stool, change in bowel habits, diarrhea, incontinence of stool, black tarry stools,: fever, loss of appetite, night sweats, weight gain, weight loss.

column1: Symptoms are poorly controlled despite using multiple prescription (Linzess, lubiprostone) and over-the-counter laxatives. The current regimen is extensive and concerning for long-term effects. The potential contribution of hormonal imbalance and pelvic floor dysfunction was discussed. She will discontinue Linzess and lubiprostone and start Motegrity.

Reports significant nausea, sometimes leading to emesis. Dicyclomine provides insufficient relief and has a side effect of constipation. Will start Compazine for better nausea control, which does not cause constipation.

Recently started on oral estradiol and increased testosterone by her GYN. The potential link between hormonal changes and GI dysmotility was discussed. Improvement in GI symptoms will be monitored as her hormone levels stabilize.

Discussed as a possible etiology for her refractory constipation. If symptoms do not improve with medication changes and hormone therapy, referral to Dr. Baucom for anorectal manometry and balloon expulsion testing will be considered.
Start Motegrity once daily. Discontinue Linzess and lubiprostone.
May continue Miralax, 1-4 capfuls daily as needed for constipation.
Start Compazine, one tablet every 6-8 hours as needed for nausea and vomiting.
Prescriptions for Motegrity and Compazine sent to Alpine Drug.
Follow up in the clinic in 6 weeks to assess response to medication changes.
Advised to reach out if symptoms worsen or do not improve.

9/6/2024 (Lacey): 24 y/o M presents for hospital follow up on severe ulcerative pancolitis. He was discharged last week on prednisone and oral/rectal mesalamine. He is having lower abdominal pain that has gotten worse since the hospital. He's having 10-12 bowel movements a day, with hematochezia. Dicyclomine isn't helping much.

10/7/2024 (Lacey): 25 y/o M presents for follow up on severe pancolitis. After our last visit, he ended up getting admitted for infliximab administration because he was getting too sick to wait on insurance approval. He got a second dose on 9/30. He feels tremendously better. He is having 2-3 bowel movements each morning, then 1-2 in the evening. Stools are ranging from loose to formed. He's having a little blood on toilet paper with wiping, and not every time. 90% of the time, he can distinguish gas from stool to pass.

2/7/2025 (Lacey): 25 y/o M presents for follow up on ulcerative pancolitis.  He reports that he has been having significant improvement in GI symptoms, to the point of resolution.  Bowel movements are normal.  No hematochezia, no abdominal pain.  He is able to tell the difference between passing gas and stool.

Andrew Heine is a 27-year-old male with a past medical history of premature birth, ADHD, and PVCs, who presents for evaluation of persistently elevated liver enzymes. Seen with mother present. He was previously evaluated for this in 2022 by Dr. Vemula at which time serologic workup was notable for a positive smooth muscle antibody and ANA. A subsequent liver biopsy was completely normal, and his liver enzymes normalized on 07/08/2022.
Recent Abdominal ultrasound: Normal appearing liver, gallbladder, and biliary ducts. No suspicious lesions or fatty changes noted.

Recent laboratory tests last month noted a mildly elevated ALT 57 with a normal AST 26, alkaline phosphatase 69, and total bilirubin 0.4. CBC was normal with platelets of 290. TSH was normal. Cholesterol and triglycerides were elevated.

The primary concern is persistently elevated liver enzymes over the past few years. Risk factors for MASH include a history of elevated cholesterol and triglycerides, which is reported to be familial. He was recently started on rosuvastatin for hyperlipidemia. He denies symptoms of abdominal pain, nausea, jaundice, or abdominal distension. He reports rare alcohol use and denies the use of herbal supplements or smoking. No family history of liver disease or cirrhosis.

The patient has a history of diverticulosis complicated by diverticulitis as noted on previous CT scan imaging. We discussed the pathophysiology and natural history of diverticular disease. We focused our discussion on reducing such complications through a high fiber diet with OTC fiber supplementation along with limiting red meats and continued exercise. Per guidelines, given patient's recent episode of acute diverticulitis he should have a colonoscopy to assess for extent of diverticulosis and presence of persistent inflammation, as well as for additional lesions, including colorectal neoplasia and non-infectious colitis, which can produce similar symptoms. However, this is safest to be done 6 to 8 weeks after his episode to assure resolution of his diverticulitis prior to the procedure. This is in hopes of lowering risk of a potential complication, like perforation.

column1: 20 yo F w/ PMHx of IBS presents for f/u. Last seen on 7/18/25 to establish care and discuss GERD, regurgitation, N/V, changes in bowel habits, blood/mucus in stool, and abdominal pain. She underwent bidirectional scopes on 8/11/25. EGD showed no endoscopic esophageal abnormality to explain dysphagia, though dilation was noted along w/ erythematous gastric mucosa. Colonoscopy revealed hemorrhoids on perianal exam and patchy congestion in the terminal ileum, and the remainder of the colon appeared normal. Pathology showed minimal chronic gastritis, mild nonspecific chronic inflammation in the distal esophagus, and acute ileitis. Pentasa (mesalamine) was recommended but not started due to cost/insurance issues.

Today, she reports ongoing GI sx, which she believes are IBS-related. She describes epigastric pain 1-2x/day, alternating bowel habits, and infrequent rectal bleeding (a few times per year, last episode prior to colonoscopy). She has 1-3 BMs daily or every other day, typically Bristol 3-5. Abdominal pain occurs after meals and presents as mid-abdominal cramping or bloating, sometimes sharp, resolving within about 30 minutes. She also notes frequent belching and suspects she may be swallowing too much air. Reflux/heartburn occurs once per week, and she experiences chest pain 2-3x/week. She discontinued acid suppression following EGD. Currently using water and Costco fiber gummies for sx relief. Since her colonoscopy, she has had increased urinary frequency (14-15x/day) and is unsure if it is related. She has also increased her water intake. Recently seen by PCP, UA was done, and UTI was suspected, w/ abx starting tomorrow. No other current UGI or LGI sx reported.

column1: Patient is a 79-year-old white female who presents today for follow-up on increased GERD symptoms. She reports her increased symptoms started about 4 to 6 weeks ago, and is having breakthrough reflux symptoms several times a week. Of note patient has been on GLP-1 medications in the past, most recently on Mounjaro, states she stopped this 6 weeks ago. Patient states she is taking her pantoprazole 40 mg in the morning, does not take with food. She is also using Pepcid AC over-the-counter as needed. We discussed any changes in her diet, exercise, medication regimen approximately a month ago that could be contributing to her increased GERD symptoms. She reports she was on a weeklong cruise to Alaska. She reports that she is eating larger meals, eating late at night, and reports since being off the GLP-1 she is hungry all day long and eats all day. She states she typically does not eat breakfast, does not eat until around 1030 or 11:00 AM. She reports she often eats late at night and lays down quickly afterwards. She reports burning in the midsternal area that is often relieved with over-the-counter Pepcid. She denies any overt abdominal pain, no hemoptysis, no nausea or vomiting and no weight loss.

We discussed need to improve lifestyle changes to help lower her GERD symptoms. Recommend weight loss, smaller frequent meals, eating 3 to 4 hours prior to lying flat at night, avoiding acidic and spicy foods, and avoiding GLP-1 medications. We will increase her pantoprazole to twice daily dosing and ensure patient is taking medication with food. She will follow-up with me in 6 weeks for symptom check or sooner if new or worsening symptoms arise.

Axel was seen last year with persistent diarrhea following liver transplant presumed due to EPI based on stool testing for which he was being treated with Creon. He was actually having bouts of urgency and so was advised to take a bottle of mag citrate followed by nightly Miralax. These measures yielded no appreciable improvement. He stopped the Creon over a year ago due to the expense (almost $5000/mo) and believes the diarrhea was somewhat worse off the medication. He has continued to have ongoing diarrhea since. He typically has 4-5 loose or watery stools/d, usually after meals, which may at times be ""explosive"" with ""a lot of gas"". This may be associated with considerable urgency to the point of incontinence. He uses an OTC antidiarrheal (? Imodium) which helps ""a little bit"". As before, there is no associated abd pain or cramping and he notes only occasional mild bleeding from hemorrhoids. His weight is stable. He has noted that the diarrhea seems to subside whenever he takes antibiotics. Abd/pelvis CT last month was negative.

Janet Coger is a 69 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Since our last visit, her Ozempic dosage was decreased due to continued burning abdominal pain. Her abdominal pain has improved on lower dose. She does report intermittent RLQ pain that seems to be correlated with constipation. She is taking Miralax but admits she has not been consistent with daily use. She is trying to be better about this. She did run out of fiber gummies 3-4 days ago and says she can tell she has not been taking them. She does have Hyoscyamine at home but has not taken in several months and forgot what it was for. She denies blood in stool. She is back to taking PPI once daily which seems to be keeping reflux controlled, especially now that her Ozempic was decreased. She has lost 14 pounds since her last visit and says her blood sugars have rarely been above 120-140.

Jessica is back following up with me for some recent symptoms that she has been having. She is reporting symptoms of fullness or discomfort in the epigastric area that feels like a brick and she puts her fist to the right in the epigastric area. She does not feel well after meals. She is having some thick mucus and in the back of her throat. She is occasionally getting queasy or nauseous. She induced vomiting 1 time to make yourself feel better last week. Interestingly, after bowel movements she sometimes feels a little brief nausea or chills. She is moving her bowel daily after coffee but she says it might not move if she did have coffee. She does not feel like she empties well.

She is not drinking alcohol. She has been taking vitamin B12 supplement. She briefly took some sort of colostrum recovery supplement. I started her on omeprazole 20 mg daily last week and she has had mild improvement over the weekend. She has not had to take any Zofran but I gave her some of that as well. She has lost 13 pounds since we have seen her last through a concerted effort at healthier diet and some increase in physical activity.  We tested with h.pylori breath test back in Nov 2023 and that was negative.  Her last EGD was in 2016 and was essentially negative with negative biopsies from all three areas.  She is not on opiates or drinking alcohol.

Wayne is following up with me in GI clinic with his history of esophageal stricture, small hiatal hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis. He has had EGD with dilation in 2011, 2017, and now 2025. He has not had severe stricture each time I have dilated him up to 18 mm with mucosal effect. Biopsies in 2017 and 2025 show eosinophils and most recently there were 55 eosinophils per high-power field in the upper endoscopy done this year. I put him on the pantoprazole after the procedure and I was seeing him back in follow-up. He reports that he was not having heartburn or chest discomfort just dysphagia that led to the presentation in the referral earlier this year in April.

He has been on proton pump inhibitor for several months since the procedure and he reports that his swallowing function is pretty normal and he is not having any reflux or chest discomfort. He also denies any lower GI symptoms. He has had 2 colonoscopies 1 was in 2005 with polyps and then most recently we did 1 in July 2020 where he had 2 tubular adenomas and hemorrhoids found and a 7-year follow-up was recommended.
He also mentioned that after our discussion following the procedure, he has been trying to perform and 2 food elimination diet with milk and wheat.

Barbara is back in GI clinic follow-up of her left-sided ulcerative colitis. The last time that I saw disease activity was in 2015 that was right around the time that we started azathioprine. She was on balsalazide at that time and she continues on those 2 medicines today and she has been in remission ever since. We did colonoscopy in May of this year there was no disease activity there were several polyps which were tubular adenomas.

I did lower her azathioprine from 200 mg down to 150 mg at that visit. She has not had any flare or increase in symptoms since then. It is been about 3 months. Her bowel movements have slowed down a little bit since she has been started on Ozempic. She is moving them every other day and are getting a little firm. She is not having any reflux or dysphagia. She does have a ventral hernia she is not having any pain or problems from that. She tells me that she avoids gluten and it causes gas and bloating and it makes her want to eat more.

column1: Denise Reynolds is a 60 year old female who is seen today for follow-up. Dr. Moore started her on Reglan empirically for suspected gastroparesis. She has been taking 5 mg TID and says she cannot tell that it has helped at all. She is still having frequent nausea and vomiting of undigested food. She continues to report early satiety, excessive bloating, and periumbilical pain. She continues to have dysphagia that she says seems to be worsening. She has difficulty with solids and liquids as well as randomly on occasion. She was dilated with no resistance at 54 Fr in September. It was not especially beneficial. She has had a modified swallow study with speech that was negative as well as normal esophageal manometry. She is doing better in regards to her lower GI symptoms. She could not tolerate Colestipol and Cholestyramine powder was too expensive. She has been taking 3 Welchol tablets before bed. She is not having as much urgency and less frequent episodes of incontinence. She does have BRBPR that comes and goes periodically. She is not taking Loperamide at all as she says it makes her feel more bloated. She has not had any constipation lately. She has remained on 20 mg of Omeprazole and 10 mg of Amitriptyline.

Denise is back in clinic today for follow-up. She was started on 20 mg of Voquezna at last visit. She does feel that her reflux is much better on Voquezna. She took 20 mg for 8 weeks and is now taking 10 mg. She denies any change in her dysphagia. She has had increased nausea since last visit but denies vomiting. We did discontinue her Reglan as she didn't feel it was helping. She reported that Welchol was working quite well. However, she has recently had more frequent episodes of diarrhea and fecal incontinence. She has no warning when this will happen. She is taking 3 Welchol capsules at bedtime. She has not had any recent rectal bleeding. She has no new symptoms to report.

Denise returns today for a follow-up visit. She is stable and has not had any major change in symptoms since our last visit. We did put her back on Reglan 5 mg TID to see if would help her nausea. She says that it has helped some. She has not had any adverse side effects. She continues to have fairly good control of her reflux on 10 mg of Voquezna. She continues to report dysphagia that remains unchanged. She had some BRBPR on Saturday and Sunday last weekend but that has since resolved. Her diarrhea and fecal incontinence remain unchanged. She is still taking 2 Welchol tablets BID which does not seem to be quite as effective as when she initially started it, but she can still tell a noticeable difference if she misses a dose.

column1: Overall, she is stable with no major change in her symptoms. She does feel that Reglan has helped decrease the severity of her nausea and would like to continue it. She has not experience any adverse reactions. However, we again discussed what to watch for and to stop the Reglan immediately and notify our office should she experience any of those symptoms. Her main complaint continues to be her chronic, uncontrollable diarrhea with frequent episodes of incontinence. She initially had a fairly good response to Welchol but it has since become less effective. She had a sacral nerve stimulator placed in early 2023. She has not followed up with Dr. Tantchou since then. I recommended she request a follow-up appointment to discuss if adjustments or reprogramming may be warranted to optimize effectiveness. She will follow-up with Dr. Moore in 4 months or sooner with any problems. She did request an updated letter similar to the ones we have written in the past that she can provide to her employer regarding the status of her GI conditions.

Reglan side effects were discussed with patient, patient education materials generated by EMR. Especially tardive dyskinesia (involuntary movement of extremities, lipsmacking, grimacing, tongue motion, eye motion, finger motion, etc) which may be permanent and severely disabling and may occur even after stopping the medication. Patient understood that medication is for short term use of less than 3 months, but patient was ok for long-term/chronic use despite increased risk of side effects.  Also discussed with patient depression/suicidal ideation.  If these occur, the patient is to stop the medication immediately and call office if feels these symptoms.  Also discussed with patient somnolence/dizziness/extrapyramidal symptoms such as tremor, torticollis, akithesia, Parkinson's-like symptoms.  Patient understood that all these may be irreversible and risk increases with chronic use.
Follow-up with gastroenterologist JDM in 3-4 months"

column1: Frederick is a very pleasant 88-year-old male with a BMI of 23 with multiple issues including diabetes and cardiovascular disease however appearing younger than his stated age that presents to the office today to see me in consultation from Dr. Marsden with abnormal liver imaging. The consultation does state that there may be either fibrosis versus cirrhosis of the liver. Fred clinically feels well, was not experiencing any symptoms, is not clear to me why the testing was performed however presumably it was because of abnormal liver enzymes. His weight is stable, he has no high risk activities or habits, no alcohol consumption, no symptoms or signs of encephalopathy, no GI bleeding. He is on anticoagulation and does have some ecchymosis present but no jaundice. No signs or symptoms of GI bleeding. No previous history of liver disease in the past.

7. GERD. Normal EGD in 2021. She reports previous allergy to pantoprazole. Recommend switching omeprazole to 30 minutes prior to the morning meal along with on-demand famotidine.

8. Personal history of sporadic adenoma. We discussed current guidelines regarding surveillance in the setting of a history of adenomatous polyps especially those removed by EMR technique. Repeat colonoscopy 3 years (2026)

The patient reports ongoing episodes of diarrhea, which occur approximately once a month. The diarrhea is described as a ""purge,"" with the first bowel movement being a forceful flush, followed by three subsequent episodes of complete diarrhea. The patient notes that the diarrhea is black in color and occurs without warning, making it difficult to reach the bathroom in time and often resulting in soiled underwear. On days without diarrhea, bowel movements are normal in form and appearance. The patient has been taking Imodium every other day to manage symptoms and is concerned about the safety of this frequency. The patient is about a year and a half out from a colonoscopy, during which these symptoms were not present. There have been no recent changes in medication except for the continued use of meloxicam, which has been taken for a long time for knee pain following a knee replacement. The patient is unsure how much meloxicam helps with knee symptoms but feels unable to discontinue it. Previous stool studies, including tests for pancreatic enzyme insufficiency and bacterial overgrowth, were normal.
- Schedule flexible sigmoidoscopy (mini colonoscopy) to obtain colon biopsies for diagnosis.
- If microscopic colitis is confirmed, discontinue meloxicam.

It was great speaking with you today, here is a reminder of what we talked about: We will set up a flexible sigmoidoscopy, which is a short procedure to help find out what is causing your diarrhea. If the test shows you have microscopic colitis, you may need to stop taking meloxicam. For now, you should keep taking Motrin as discussed. We will let you know what to do next after we get the results.

column1: 1. Abdominal pain, acute, right upper quadrant - R10.11 (Primary). Resolved. Abdominal pain has resolved. No change in bowel habit to warrant repeat xifaxan. Prior endoscopic studies unremarkable. CT rather unremarkable. Has had sonogram and fibroscan.

2. MEG pain: Recent ER visit for CP/EMG pain. Work up was unremarkable. Continue with MEG pain that worsens postprandial. Abdominal exam with TTP over MEG region. Will increase Omeprazole 40gm to BID dosing and continue Famotidine 10mg BID. Will proceed with EGD to evaluate for significant luminal pathology such as esophagitis, hiatal hernia, strictures, Barrett's esophagus, vs other. I have discussed with herthe importance of avoiding trigger foods (spicy, greasy, fatty, fried foods, caffeine and acidic foods), elevating the head of the bed, not eating after 7PM, avoid tight fitting clothes and avoid smoking/alcohol.

Tandy Clements is a 54 year old female patient who is seen today for an initial visit. Here due to changes in bowel habits, onset 6 months ago. Diarrhea 4-5 times a day, moderate bloating and gas. Rectal bleeding with each BM, blood is bright red. Stools also contain mucus. Denies fever, vomiting, weight loss. On day 5 on Augmentin but has not felt any improvement. Labs 3/30: bacteroides detected, normal liver enzymes, white count 6, hgb 14, platelets 220.

5/5/22: Follow up to procedure. Colonoscopy 4/27: proctitis, erythema and friability in the distal rectum, moderate proctitis. Bx: diffuse active chronic colitis. She feels okay felt better on higher dose of prednisone has tapered down to 10mg. she is only able to take Prednisone, she cannot take mesalamine because she has a severe reaction to Aspirin. denies fever, melena, weight loss.

7/8/22: Follow up - doing well, she has reduced Budesonide to one a day because she was having Headaches, back pain and Anxiety episodes. she did not take Mesalamine because she has allergy to NSAIDs. BM are loose, mucus and bleeding. Labs: Fecal calprotectin >8000. Denies fever, melena, nausea. Labs June 29: HGB 14, Live enzymes normal,creatinine normal. Colonoscopy: moderate to severe proctitis, erythema and Friability.

8/3/22: Here for follow up, Entyvio infusion was 1 week ago, She has improved so much after the infusion. No abd pain, no fever/chills, no melena. Labs 8/1: glucose normal, creatinine normal, liver enzymes normal, albumin normal, protein low, hgb 13, white count normal, Fecal protectin pending. also on prednisone taper, on 10mg now. BM are better, small bm daily, some other days she has no BM. mild rectal bleeding. when her stomach flares she also has knee pains.

8/11/22: Here for follow up, she had a reaction after her second Entyvio infusion. after her fist dose she only had a headache for 3 days, took some tylenol. 2nd infusion she was flush and her BP was elevated. she has mild chills and sweats, if she takes a nap she wakes up feeling better. Her gut feels good. She takes Zyrtec daily but had not taken it in a few days because she was on steroids. has gained about 15lbs. denies fever, chills, melena, vomiting. Labs 8/1: liver enzymes normal, HGB 13, Fecal calprotectin 111.

11/14/22: 3 month follow up - Feels better, is having to take a little more benedryl before Infusion, and they are infusing slower and is not having any side effects to the medication. In October she was a stressful month for her and found that around week 6 she started having mild flare. Says her stomach just doesnt feel right and not settled around week 6-7. Denies fever, chills, melena. She cannot take any mesalamine she has a reaction.

3/1/23: Here for follow up. She had a sever anaphylactic reaction to Entyvio 1 week ago, she started Entyvio infusion in July. Taking zyrtec and benedryl for the last week, and still feels she needs them. she feels well over all No abd pain, no bleeding. BM are good. She is seeing a cardiologist and will be getting a cardiac work up in few weeks.  Fecal calprotectin 43. Labs 2/13: cholesterol 200, HDL a little elevated, kidneys normal, liver enzymes normal, A1C 5, wbc 5, HGB 13, CRP 1.5.

5/3/23: here for follow up to UC, Cardiac clearance  a day or so ago, she started Zeposia last Friday on the starter pack. BP has been stable. took Budesonide for last 1 month because she was flaring in between medications, off of Entyvio infusion for 1 month. Thursday she had a large dose of Prednisone tablets, she felt better 3 days after. she has not done the labs since she just started new Zeposia. says she is still seeing Cardiologist Dr. Ganim and is aware of new medication. Feeling tired and with occasional upper back pain for the last few days.

6/5/23: Here for follow up, she is doing well, feeling well over all on Zeposia. And she is doing well, one BM a day, if she eats more adventurous she tends to have more BM. bently for occ cramps. No weight loss, no bleeding. Insurance is covering mediation well $0 copay. Has been on full dose Zeposia for 1 month, states she gets very tired 3 hours after taking her medication and she sleeps very good and has some very vivid/weird dreams, she is in a support group on Facebook who are also on this medication. Creatinine 0.7, wbc 4, hgb 13, platelets 200, liver enzymes in the teens.

8/7/2023- pt is here for a follow -up pt is still taking Zeposia and she thinks  shes been having shortness of breath, swellings in her hands and legs due to taking this meds she stays she was put on water pills because of the swelling. she states shes also been having sinus problems and she thinks it might be a reaction to the meds shes taking because shes never had sinus problems before. no abd pain no bleeding. Over all feels ok.

10/11/2023-pt is here for lab work and 2 month follow up, pt states she no longer has dirrhea and no longer has mucus or blood. pt states she cant eat dairy or fried it gose through her and has loose stool. pt states she she feels much better. pt is still on Zeposia/ Bentyl  daily. lab work show WBC 3.5 HGB13 CAL PRE 52.

01/15/2024- pt is here for a follow-up she states at time she dose get some spasms and takes medication for it and helps her. she states she goes about 3-5 times a day. she states she started working again and thinks what's causing her to have loose stool.she take zeposia daily and she feels great on it. labs done in 11/2023 - all hep virus is negative  wbc 4 hgb 14 plt 200 aic 5.6 alt 16 ast 14.  pt no longer takes prednisone.  pt feels good overall no abd pain no fever or chills.

08/14/24- Pt is here today for a 6 month follow up. She is doing very well overall. She is eating well and has gained some weight since shes eating well. She is only on Zeposia, doing well on it and her cardiologist states that she is doing well on it. Labs done 7/20 WBC 4,  HGB 13, Platelets 182, CRP <3. Fecal Cal is still pending. She had a small flare and took prednisone a few months ago but the flare subsided quickly. She states that at times she has 2-3 BMs daily but then will change to not having a BM for a day or two.

02/25/25- Tandy Clements is a 57 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Pt is here for a 6 month lab follow up. She is doing well overall. She is eating well and denies any symptoms. She is no longer on prednisone and is taking Bentyl PRN. She is only on Zeposia for her colitis. Patient is a 65-year-old gentleman who was seen in consultation at the request of Dr. Baros for an opinion regarding change in bowel habits. Patient was in his usual state of health until 3 months ago when he developed diarrhea characterized by watery loose stools. Normally has 1 bowel movement every other day but started having a bowel movement every other day to multiple times a day that were watery and loose. Patient states that ever since he had his prostate removed he has little urge to have a bowel movement but denies any fecal incontinence. He does describe gas, bloating and borborygmi and also has some sharp periumbilical intermittent abdominal pain that last for less than a minute. He describes no precipitating factors and nothing seems to make it better or worse. He denies any rectal bleeding, melena, fever, unintentional weight loss. Prior to the onset of his symptoms he denies any travel, sick contacts, new medicines, over-the-counter medicines, herbal medicines. He does have a diagnosis of lactose intolerance. Laboratory studies done in July 2025 showed a normal CBC, CMP and TSH. A CT scan done recently showed findings suggestive of possible mesenteric panniculitis. Patient last had a colonoscopy done in 2013.

column1: Ms. Last is a 71 year old WF with a history of ileal Crohn’s c/b recurrent SBOs s/p resection of stricture in the TI (7/2020) & osteoporosis, & uveitis. She is here today for follow up with IBD team.

- Most recent colonoscopy: 01/07/2025 (Dr. Tsiakos)- Evidence of a previous ileo-colonic anastomosis was seen. Healthy appearing anastomosis. Normal appearing colon and TI. Path: acute ileitis. Normal colon bx's. No dysplasia.
- Current meds:  IFX 5mg/kg every 4 weeks. Moved to every 6 weeks 04/15/2025
- SB evaluation/imaging: 9/22/2023 MRE: No active IBD or obstruction
- EIMs: +eye issues- visual loss R eye 4/2023. +uveitis. Joint pain- single joint, dominant hand
- 12/2015 Humira 40mg every 2 weeks + Pentasa. 2/2018 Reloaded Humira & increased Humira 40mg weekly (d/t low drug level). Tried adding MTX, did not tolerate.
- 8/21/2020- current Stelara 90 mg SQ every 8 weeks--> CD controlled but developed uveitis and changing to IFX q4 weeks per ophthalmologist's request
- 11/09/2023 changed to IFX 5mg/kg every weeks to cover severe uveitis AND Crohn's
Please see CCM enrollment visit 09/01/2023 for complete history.
She has seen several providers over the years. She started with CRS in 2010.

Briefly, June 2013 presented with abdominal pain and intermittent rectal bleeding. Work up with Dr. Eidem included  Labs c/w IDA. 7/2013 CT showed long segment of SB enhancement concerning for Crohn’s with possible small fistula. 8/2013 scope showed stx at the IC valve with ileal ulcerations. Scope could not be passed into the TI. Treated with budesonide, Flagyl, Cipro. AZA 100mg/day added in 9/2013. In 2015 was admitted several times with recurrent SBO and started Humira 12/2015 & optimized at 40mg weekly. Did well for several years until 2019, presented with diarrhea, N/V, and abdominal pain. CTE showed long segment of active CD with luminal narrowing. Surgery was recommended but she opted to hold off. 08/2020 changed to Stelara and a few weeks later admitted with recurrent SBO and required TPN and underwent surgery. Continued Stelara every 8 weeks following surgery and did well well. Controlled constipation with daily Miralax.

In 2023 started to have eye issues, started with what she thought was a floater. Seen by ophthalmology and told fine. Symptoms progressed to visual changes. Seen by cornea and 4 retina specialists. Eventually diagnosed with macular degeneration and lost vision in right eye. Later in 2023 she established with Dr. Rene Choi, who specializes uveitis. After. complete work up he diagnosed as uveitis & felt related to her IBD and requested moving back to TNFi. Started back on IFX 5mg/kg every 4 weeks, per ophthalmologist's recommendation.
Monday saw internist. She extensive labs and 9 things were out of range, including ANA homogenous 1:160, speckled. BUN 31. calcium ion 18 (20-50 normal), sodium 147 (H). Labs drawn at CPL.
Reports joint in finger is swollen on one hand & can hurt with overuse.

From our standpoint states doing well overall. If does not use glycerin suppository she has incomplete stool. She tries not using suppository but uses before going out to avoid leakage. No abdominal pain or bleeding.
Reviewed labs from 08/19/2025- IFX 66, no ATIs.
Discussed asking Dr. Choi if he would be ok if went ever 8 weeks on the IFX given IFX level.
Saw Dr. Choi recently. Sees him ~3 months.

Most Recent Exam & Findings: 1/7/2025 - Evidence of a previous ileo-colonic anastomosis was seen. Healthy appearing anastomosis. Normal appearing colon and TI. Path: acute ileitis. Normal colon bx's. No dysplasia.
Notes: +4/2023 vision loss. Dx'ed macular degeneration. Undergoing work up for immune mediated cause
Stool Frequency Evaluation: No blood seen in stool.

Patient presents today for a follow-up telemedicine visit accompanied by his wife. He complains of worsening difficulty swallowing over the past 6 weeks. Of note he does have a history of esophageal cancer and is in remission. He was on antibiotics for a foot infection and follows with an infectious disease PA Allison who reached out to Dr. Guirl regarding his dysphagia. Of note earlier in the month he did have thrush that he was treated for. This morning he attempted to eat a sandwich but then felt that it was getting stuck in his throat and he ended up coughing it up. He does have heartburn for which he takes esomeprazole 40 mg once a day in the evening. He otherwise denies any issues with dysphagia to pills or liquids, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, gas or bloating, changes in bowel habits, blood in his stool, melena, unintentional weight loss or fevers. Of note his oncologist ordered a PET scan which is scheduled for tomorrow.

column1: Rebecca is a 69-year-old female presenting for follow-up. She has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease, esophageal stricture, and a history of an adenomatous polyp found on a previous colonoscopy.

Rebecca reports that her gastroesophageal reflux disease is well-controlled with Nexium 40 mg daily. She denies any heartburn issues. Her condition has also improved significantly with weight loss. She was diagnosed with prediabetes which progressed to diabetes. This motivated her to change her diet and mindset. Her physician, Dr. Grinsfelder, prescribed Ozempic, which has resulted in a weight loss of approximately 100 pounds. She reports feeling much better since losing weight. She reports loose skin as a consequence of the weight loss but has no plans for plastic surgery.

A previous colonoscopy performed in July 2020 by Dr. Stevens revealed a 5-millimeter adenomatous polyp, which was removed. A surveillance colonoscopy is therefore due in September 2025, five years after the initial finding. She has a history of esophageal stricture, with the last dilation performed in May 2021. Esophageal biopsies at that time were normal with no evidence of Barrett's esophagus. Her care was previously managed by Dr. Casey, then Dr. Stevens, before I assumed her care last year.
She has no questions regarding the upcoming colonoscopy. An upper endoscopy is not indicated at this time due to her well-controlled symptoms.

column1: David Dubuc is a 50 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit.He presents for routine follow-up after recent genetic testing as below. He had initial Lynch syndrome analysis at time of surgical resection and 2014 and DNA mismatch repair proteins for MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2 were positive indicating normal gene products. However, subsequent serologic testing showed an abnormality of the NTHL1 gene, and for this reason he presents for reevaluation. He is generally asymptomatic although does have occasional difficulty swallowing commensurate with history of eosinophilic esophagitis, but no solid food bolus impactions. There is no abdominal pain, hematochezia, or melena. Subsequent colonoscopic surveillance have shown adenomas on each subsequent exam. There is no family history of upper gastrointestinal, colorectal, or breast carcinoma. His first-degree family members have undergone screening, specifically siblings

He completed adjuvant systemic therapy with FOLFOX in 5/2015 and began a clinical trial evaluating regorafenib after completion of standard therapy but had difficulties with mucositis and pain and withdrew therapy in July 2015
Labs 2024-hematocrit 42, MCV 90, platelets 322, normal chemistries, normal hepatic enzymes, CEA 2.5. CTs have been unremarkable and no additional scans are recommended in the absence of symptoms

Lynch syndrome analysis 7/2025-pathogenic mutation p.Q90*/p.!90*consistent with pathogenic mutation of the NTHL1 gene. No additional pathogenic mutations or variants of unknown significance or gross deletions or duplications were detected. Current screening considerations include starting at age 25-30 with colonoscopy every 1 to 2 years if polyps are found
Cecal adenocarcinoma diagnosed 2014. Immunostain for DNA mismatch repair proteins MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2 pos indicating normal gene products, speaking against MSI-related malignancy
EGD and colonoscopy 2017-eosinophilic esophagitis, single tubular adenoma
EGD and colonoscopy 2018-eosinophilic esophagitis with focal distal esophageal stricture dilated to 18 mm, normal colonoscopy
EGD and colonoscopy 2020-eosinophilic esophagitis with focal distal esophageal stricture dilated to 15 mm, antral gastropathy, 3 small adenomas

column1: We reviewed what is known about the NTHL1 gene mutation and potential association with early onset and polyposis syndrome. This is thought to be a rare, autosomal recessive condition resulting in greater risk for multiple cancers including colorectal and small intestinal tumors, affecting DNA repair leading to greater accumulation of mutations and tumor development. A wide range of cancers are potentially associated with these mutations including colorectal, breast, endometrial, brain, and spinal cord tumors. Surveillance is currently recommended every 2 years beginning at age 18. Endoscopy is recommended at least every 5 years beginning at age 25 as well as a brain MRI for meningioma at diagnosis with follow-up imaging in those with signs and/or symptoms of meningioma. As this is inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion, the assumption would be both of David's parents were probably heterozygous and his siblings would have a 50% chance of being a carrier and 25% chance of being affected as well as a 25% chance of having either.

In this setting, colonoscopic surveillance is recommended at 2-year intervals, along with upper endoscopy at time of next colonoscopy. I also encouraged screening by MRI given potential association with meningioma. He and his wife will also seek formal genetic counseling regarding her candidacy for testing as it may impact decisions regarding surveillance for their children.

Novella Lewis  is a 86 year old   female  who is seen today for a follow-up visit. She presents to clinic today with complaints of diarrhea intermittently with loose bms 4-5 times a day which is usually after eating. Denies any nausea or vomiting. Admits to having some incontinence. She admits to rectal pain since her brain bleed in March. No brbpr or black stools. She admits to new onset incontinence with rectal pain with sitting but no pain with bms. No abnormal weight loss. No family history of colon cancer.

Novella Lewis is a 88 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit for fecal continence. Patient complains of fecal incontinence, which has been ongoing for the last several years, but has appeared to be worsening. She is now experiencing incontinence a few times a week where she has accidental evacuation of mushy stools without sensation. Her bowel habits have remained at baseline with 2-3 bowel movements every other day at a 5, 2, or 4 on the BSS, and often does require straining to have bowel movements. Patient also complains of constant urge to have a bowel movement despite not being able to evacuate. She does have a history of a hysterectomy, but has not had any vaginal births. Patient denies feelings of any bulges from her vagina or rectum. Patient also denies melena, hematochezia, rectal pain, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, unintentional weight loss, or night sweats.

Novella Lewis is a 89 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit for coli consult. Patient continues to report intermittent diarrhea with occasional fecal incontinence. She was having a difficult time reporting the extent of her loose bowel movements or incontinence. However, she reports that she can go up to 4 days or a week without any bowel movements, and then have days where she has 3-4 bowel movements with loose stools. She believes that she has the looser bowel movements up to 3 times a week. Patient was unable to report the frequency of incontinence, but states that she often will use the restroom and see which she stools in her undergarments without even knowing that she had fecal soilage. She also reports abdominal bloating and constant nausea x 6 months, but without vomiting. She is tolerating a normal diet and her weight has been stable. Patient states that she does take a stool softener as needed when she gets constipated, and is not utilizing Imodium. She has utilized Metamucil the past, but states this caused increase in bowel movements. Patient also denies melena, hematochezia, rectal pain, abdominal pain, vomiting, dysphagia, GERD sx, decreased appetite, unintentional weight loss, or night sweats. Patient now reports a history of partial colectomy secondary to diverticulitis over 20 years ago.

column1: Novella Lewis is a pleasant 89-year-old female with a past medical history of GERD, chronic diarrhea, diverticular disease, colon polyps, HTN, CKD, and sleep apnea who presents to clinic for a follow up on fecal incontinence and chronic diarrhea along with personal history of colon polyps. Patient is under recall for surveillance colonoscopy due this year. She continues to report occasional fecal incontinence with intermittent loose bowel movements, which has been ongoing for several years.  Pt denies alarm features. She has had extensive evaluation to include stool studies, SIBO breath test, and colonoscopy that have been benign/negative. Therefore, I do continue to suspect that her loose bowel movements are likely functional in nature and incontinence is 2/2 pelvic floor dysfunction and poor anal sphincter tone as noted during previous evaluation. She has declined proceeding with further evaluation at the pelvic floor clinic due to location. Therefore, I recommend that she start soluble fiber (Banatrol) to help bulk up her stools, utilize Imodium as needed, and continue Kegel exercises to strengthen the pelvic floor. In regard to her being due for surveillance colonoscopy, we discussed the risks and benefits of proceeding with endoscopic evaluation given her age with evidence of only 1 small adenomatous polyp on colonoscopy 3 years ago. Patient preferred to hold off for now, but will discuss this again at follow-up. Patient expressed understanding and agreed with plan.

column2: Gradual titration of fiber supplementation discussed (Benefiber, Metamucil, Citrucel.)

Irwin Salvador is a 79 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Since last visit, he has increased PPI to twice daily dosing without any relief in cough. He also notes taking Gaviscon which he did not find helpful. He did complete labs and US as below.  He did recently undergo EGD given complaints of chronic cough. Additionally, he reports seeing ENT with reportedly unremarkable. There is no nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, dysphagia, odynophagia. Additionally he denies any change in bowel habits or rectal bleeding. He does have history of chronic hepatitis B, however was recently lost to follow-up. Last visit with our office was in 2021. He did recently undergo laboratory studies in May 2025 which showed nonreactive hepatitis B surface antibody, reactive hepatitis B core antibody, normal AFP, nonreactive hepatitis B surface antigen, hepatitis B virus DNA less than 10.

Labs May 2025: Bili 0.8, alk phos 63, AST 21, ALT 14, hepatitis B surface antibody nonreactive, hepatitis B core antibody total reactive, normal AFP, nonreactive hepatitis B surface antigen, hepatitis B virus DNA <10

EGD/colonoscopy 2021: 6 cm hiatal hernia. Gastric fundic polyp. Otherwise normal EGD. Diverticulosis. 3 polyps, largest 6 mm. Internal hemorrhoids. Otherwise normal screening colonoscopy.

column1: Hepatitis B: Most recent labs showed negative hepatitis B surface antigen, positive hepatitis B core antibody, negative hepatitis B surface antibody. Will continue to monitor Hep B DNA and ALT every 6 months.
Hepatic fibrosis: Given presence of hepatic fibrosis and longstanding hepatitis B, he needs ongoing radiographic surveillance with ultrasound and AFP every 6 months.
CRC screening: Given his age and results of last colonoscopy it is not mandatory that he undergo any further surveillance colonoscopies.

Hiatal hernia: I suspect this may be contributing to chronic cough, as there has been partial improvement with PPI twice daily. He may continue to use alginate's as needed after meals and at bedtime. If there is progression in symptoms, would consider surgical repair of the hiatal hernia. However per last visit, he has strong preference to avoid surgery at this time.

Pamela Koenig is a 69 yo female w/ hx of GERD, IBS, arthritis, depression, hypothyroidism. Last seen in office 2/28/2025 for periumbilical/epigastric abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Recommended Abd US, EGD/flex sig, and rx'd a course of Xifaxan. She did not complete the Abd US or EGD/flex sig due to a death in the family, and a busy summer of traveling. She did, however, complete the course of Xifaxan.
She is here TODAY for follow up.

Intermittent daily periumbilical/epigastric abdominal pain/discomfort, has been ongoing for years now. Pain/discomfort usually occurs postprandially. Often associated with abdominal bloating/gas. Pain was occurring more frequently when she saw us in clinic in February this year, but she did not follow through with EGD or Abd US due to a death in her family, and a busy summer of traveling. Did not notice improvement with PPI. She has been following a low FODMAP diet, which helps some. She met with a functional nutritionist, and is happy with their recommendations. Has also tried Dicyclomine, which helps with the pain, but caused constipation so she stopped taking it.

Longstanding history of diarrhea for >15 years. At time of last OV, was having 3-6 loose/watery BMs before 1PM daily, which was occurring irrespective of food intake. Was also having bowel urgency and occasional FI. After last OV, she completed a course of Xifaxan which she states helped, but she has now become constipated. In June, she called our office and was recommended to take Miralax 255g in 64oz of water over two days. She did this, with good effect. Now has daily small BMs, usually Bristol type 2-3. Occasionally still has diarrhea with Bristol type 5 BMs, but infrequent. Currently not on a daily bowel regimen. Drinks adequate water. Tries to stay active. Admits to poor dietary fiber intake. Not on a fiber supplement.

Previously on Pantoprazole 40mg daily, but stopped after last OV because she didn't feel like it was helping her abdominal pain. Since stopping PPI, only has rare pyrosis, about every 3-4 weeks. States she belches frequently.
Denies hematochezia, melena, nausea, vomiting, fever, chills, dysphagia, odynophagia, and unintentional weight loss.
- EGD 1/25/2023 - gastritis, HH, Bx: reactive gastropathy, no celiac or h pylori
- Colonoscopy 1/25/2023 - mild L side diverticulosis, TA, grade 1 IH

He does report less soiling and drainage through the fistula with fiber supplementation. Additionally, the patient has been experiencing infraumbilical abdominal discomfort and bloating. column1: 1. Epigastric pain: DDx. includes GERD v. gastritis v. dyspepsia v. peptic ulcer disease v. gastric outlet obstruction v. gastroparesis v. biliary colic v. constipation v. pancreatic disease v. centrally mediated pain syndrome v. visceral hypersensitivity v. malignancy v. abdominal wall pain. We discussed further diagnostic and management options for the various potential causes. Further diagnostic testing includes laboratory testing, imaging, and endoscopy. Will order lipase and amylase as she is concerned about her pancreas. Will also order an abdominal ultrasound.

I advised her to hold on starting iron supplements for now until we obtain iron studies due to concerns for liver injury. column1: Has congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium/CHRPE which is a benign congenital eye condition. However this can be a marker for familial adenomatous polyposis and which can cause increased risk of colon cancer. She was referred for genetic testing however it may be 6 months to 2 years before she gets into an appointment. Gave her 2 other names of the genetic counselors at both Baptist and Methodist. Will refer her to the Methodist Hospital genetic counselor, Christi Arreguin and we will send a referral. Will proceed with colonoscopy

Screening for colon cancer. Has possible diagnosis of FAP/Gardner since she does have a history of CHRPE and currently pending genetic testing. Denies any family history of colon cancer. Will proceed with colonoscopy and will give her Sutab for the colon prep

Ms. Casillas is an 81 year old patient who presents for a follow up evaluation.

Last Visit 6/25/2025: Hx SB carcinoid, s/p exlap w/ SB resection/end-to-end anastomosis 10/2014. Hx of recurrent SBO requiring exploratory laparotomy and lysis of adhesions at least 2-3x since initial exlap 2014.
-Recently hospitalized for another SBO, treated conservatively.
-- CT abdomen/pelvis w/ IV cont 6/5/25: SBO. WBC 11.4 (H), Hgb 13.5, GFR 57, LFTs WNL. 6/10/25 Normal SB follow through.

CC: Constant LUQ abdominal pain, 3/10, exacerbated by stress, with associated intermittent nausea, sometimes with vomiting, x past few months. Does not feel these are the same symptoms she has had chronically.

-EGD 8/19/2025: 2cm hiatal hernia. LA Class B esophagitis, and Irregular squamocolumnar junction in the esophagus, biopsies with mild reflux esophagitis,  and mild nonspecific chronic inflammation at SCJ. Erosive duodenitis, neg H pylori/Celiac disease.
-7/29/2025 - Gastric Emptying Mod Meal Solid - Delayed gastric emptying at 1 hour, 72%, normalizes by 4 hours, 1% retention.
- Pleased with her response to starting Omeprazole s/p EGD Aug. Prior nausea/vomiting has improved.
- Can still get LUQ pain, as previously discussed, but it is less frequent since starting Omeprazole 40 mg.
-- LUQ pain is unrelated to eating. Randomly occurring, associated upper abdominal bloating.
-- Her son, who accompanies patient today, notes she does drink a lot of sparkling water. She doesn't like water otherwise.
- Now, her chief concern has moved to lower abdominal pain/cramping associated with bowel movements, though notes the cramping occurs after defecation, not before.
- Occurring every day, after her daily BM.
- Typically having a BM daily, consistency can vary from normal to diarrhea.
-- Believes diarrhea is not related to a specific trigger food, as she eats largely the same diet daily.
- Hyoscyamine does usually help eventually ease the pain/cramping, but not always. Then has to use Tramadol for pain.
-- Infrequent use of the Tramadol. One tab every few days.
- Anxious about the lower abdominal pain, and requests a colonoscopy. Has had recent abdominal imaging, with no specific findings to explain the pain (completed at ED for SBO.)
-Has lost 8lb since last visit; attributes to improved diet, eating less sugar and carbohydrates.
- NEMH - CT abdomen/pelvis with IV contrast 9/25/2024: mild colitis. Treated with abx.
- 11/22/2024 - Stool studies: Negative for C. difficile. Calprotectin borderline - 86.

- 1/26/2024 - MR Abdomen and Pelvis without/with Contrast - Enterography - Negative MR enterography without active inflammation or bowel obstruction. Post-op changes from partial small bowel resection with anastomosis.
- Methodist ER - CT abd/pelvis w/o cont 2/3/25: no acute findings. Has had 3 surgeries for lysis of adhesions/SBO. 2/3/25: AST 52 (H), Amylase 56. Hgb 12.1.
- Methodist ER - CT abd/pelvis w/o cont 2/3/25: no acute findings. Has had 3 surgeries for lysis of adhesions/SBO. 2/3/25: AST 52 (H), Amylase 56. Hgb 12.1.
--Hx SB carcinoid, s/p exlap w/ SB resection/end-to-end anastomosis 10/2014, Dr Hall.
--Hx of recurrent SBO requiring exploratory laparotomy and lysis of adhesions at least 2-3x since initial exlap 2014.

column1: Prior chief complaints of nausea/vomiting and LUQ pain have significantly improved s/p starting omeprazole 40 mg daily after August EGD, showing LA class B esophagitis, biopsies with mild reflux and nonspecific esophagitis, and erosive duodenitis.
-LUQ associated with upper abdominal bloating, and her son notes that she does drink a lot of sparkling water.
Given her improvement on omeprazole, recommend she use famotidine 40 mg as needed when she has the intermittent left upper pain.
--If famotidine improves her pain, can discuss possible change in therapy from PPI to PCAB.
--If no improvement with the famotidine, would recommend closer monitoring for potential triggers, such as keeping a log, and avoiding carbonated beverages.
Chief concern is now post defecation lower abdominal pain/cramping, occurring daily after her bowel movement, which varies in consistency from normal to diarrhea.
-Hyoscyamine typically helpful and eventually easing symptoms, though occasionally needs to use tramadol if pain is not improved with the hyoscyamine.
-Does have anxiety about the lower abdominal pain and requests colonoscopy.
--S/p recent abdominal imaging with no specific findings to explain her abdominal cramping pain, though may be related to her known adhesive disease.
--Last colonoscopy completed in 2020, and her abdominal pain and cramping symptoms have been chronic, so do recommend proceeding with colonoscopy.

-Also recommend taking hyoscyamine, 2 tablets once daily 30 to 60 minutes before she typically has her daily bowel movement, which is consistently around 10 AM in the morning, to help prevent/limit developing the cramping pain in the first place.

Time spent in counseling and/or coordination of care (including but not limited to reviewing prior records, arranging further services, communicating further with other care providers) was at least 55 minutes with more than 50% of this time spent in face-to-face or direct telecommunication with the patient.

Bowels are regular without any diarrhea or constipation. No blood in the stool. He did not get the lab work of the gastric emptying study requested at his last office visit.

Weight is stable at 172 pounds. Appetite is good. His nausea is better. No vomiting, heartburn or dysphagia. No abdominal pain. Bowels are regular with any recent change in bowel habit. No blood in the stool. Denies early satiety.
Colonoscopy done in December 2018 revealed 2 polyps measuring 12 and 10 mm and external hemorrhoids. On pathology these polyps were tubular adenomas.
10/29/2021 CBC was normal apart from WBC 11.4. CMP was normal apart from alkaline phosphatase 126. Amylase 66 lipase 28. CRP less than 1. GGT 26.
Has lost 7 pounds since January of this year. Has long-term depression and anxiety and blames his lack of appetite to this. Has remained abstinent from alcohol.

Has nausea but no vomiting, heartburn or dysphagia. He drinks 2 shakes in a day and 1 meal in the evening. Feels his psychiatric issues are affecting his oral intake. Has been referred to a neurologist by his spine surgeon and has a scheduled appointment. He has seen a psychiatrist in the past but does not have an appointment to see 1 at this time. He will talk to his primary physician Dr. Parisi regarding this. No abdominal pain.
He has 1-2 formed bowel movements a day. No blood in the stool.
1/26/2022 CBC was normal. CMP was normal apart from blood sugar 106 and alkaline phosphatase 141. Amylase and lipase were normal. CRP 2.
2/9/2022 colonoscopy revealed sigmoid diverticulosis and external hemorrhoids. A surveillance colonoscopy in 5 years was recommended
5/27/2022 CBC was normal. CMP was normal apart from alkaline phosphatase 125. Amylase 67. Lipase 21.

Has lost 11 pounds since his last visit. He feels that this is because of ""mental issues"" affecting his ability to eat. He has loss of appetite. He has intermittent nausea but no vomiting, heartburn or dysphagia. No abdominal pain.
Bowels are regular without any recent change in bowel habit. No hematochezia or melena.

Since stopping the sertraline and started on vitamin D2 his appetite is apparently improved and his stomach feels better i.e. the nausea and discomfort has improved. He does not have any heartburn on the Prilosec 40 mg every morning. Denies any dysphagia or abdominal pain. Denies early satiety.
He has gained 7 pounds since his last visit. He could not tolerate the Skyrizi for his psoriasis.
His bowels are regular on the pancreatic enzymes. He remains on a low-fat diet. No blood in the stool or black stool.
He has not seen a urologist as yet for the large prostate.

10/17/2022 CT chest, abdomen and pelvis with contrast revealed small lung nodules, possible wall thickening versus peristalsis/lack of distention of left colon distally. Probable left renal cyst. Large irregular prostate with mass-effect, bladder wall thickening, possible bladder stone versus early excretion of contrast. Small hiatal hernia. Colonic diverticulosis.
11/11/2022 CBC was normal apart from WBC 10.9. CMP was normal apart from blood sugar 110, alkaline phosphatase 136. CEA 5.9. CA 19–9 15. Amylase and lipase were normal.
Epigastric discomfort off and on. No nausea or vomiting. No heartburn or dysphagia. Appetite has improved but varies from day-to-day. Weight is stable.
Bowels are regular without any recent change in bowel habit. No hematochezia or melena.
He is still trying to establish with a psychiatrist.

On May 2 he had a prostate biopsy done which apparently resulted in sepsis and hospitalization on May 5. He was in the hospital for 4 days and continued on antibiotics for 2 weeks after discharge. His epigastric pain has resolved now and his appetite is returned. He states that his weight at home has been stable for the past 6 months although on our scales he has lost 7 pounds since the last visit. He has been eating better but he does not take his Zenpep as prescribed. He denies any nausea, vomiting, heartburn or dysphagia. The reflux symptoms are under good control on Prilosec 40 mg every morning.

His bowels move once a day on Metamucil 1 tablespoon 3 times daily but the initial portion of the stool is hard requiring him to strain. Denies any blood in the stool or black stool. MiraLAX was effective in the past.
He now has an indwelling urinary catheter and the prostate biopsies apparently did reveal prostate cancer but no treatment has been recommended at this time.
4/13/2023 CBC and CMP were normal. Amylase 19. Lipase 31. CRP less than 1.

Very pleasant 73-year-old gentleman here today for consultation regarding bloating. Also apparently recently was hospitalized with acute pancreatitis. Since that time and perhaps even a little bit before he is endorsing abdominal bloating. He is trying to avoid certain foods such as onion and spicy foods and this has helped. column1: I reviewed the patient's medical history at length with him and discussed the risk and benefits of a colonoscopy. We discussed current guidelines regarding colon cancer screening. After reviewing the risk I think it would be advisable to not proceed to colonoscopy at this point. He is asymptomatic and has no significant family history and in addition has a significant cardiac and pulmonary history that seem to outweigh the risk of the colonoscopy. Obviously of his clinical condition should change from a gastrointestinal standpoint we will certainly reconsider. He was appreciative of this discussion and will notify me if any changes in his clinical status which may suggest the need for reevaluation

Patient is an 80-year-old gentleman who was initially seen in July 2025 for an opinion regarding abdominal pain. Patient reports a 2-month history of epigastric abdominal pain, on and off it feels like ""gas pain"". He denies any precipitating factors and nothing seems to make his symptoms better or worse. He denies any nausea, vomiting, heartburn, fever, unintentional weight loss or melena. He denies any chronic use of NSAIDs prior to the onset of his symptoms. He does have heartburn for which he is on pantoprazole daily. About a month ago he had some blood in his stool which is since resolved. He does have some dysphagia to solid food which seem to improve with PPI therapy as well. Patient last had a colonoscopy in 2020 per his history and has a history of diverticulosis. Laboratory studies in March 2025 showed a normal CBC, CMP, vitamin B12 and vitamin D level. Patient still has a gallbladder intact as well. Plan was to check abdominal ultrasound and an upper endoscopy. EGD was notable for mild reflux esophagitis, H. pylori, EOE negative. Plan was to minimize NSAIDs and a trial of pantoprazole 40 mg daily and office visit in 6 weeks to see how he is doing. As he has been on that for months, he was switched to Nexium 40 mg daily with a plan to take it 30 to 60 minutes before breakfast. Abdominal ultrasound was normal.

Patient presents today for follow-up visit. Since he was last seen, he has been taking Nexium 40 mg daily and his symptoms of epigastric abdominal pain have resolved. He does report some occasional reflux and heartburn. He denies any issues with dysphagia, nausea, vomiting, gas or bloating, changes in bowel habits, blood in his stool, melena, unintentional weight loss or fevers.
