Ms. Susie Atchison is a 73-year-old female who presents for a follow-up evaluation for lower abdominal pain with constipation. Also with NAFLD. Last seen in December 2024 for EGD/colonoscopy.

Patient states she does have occasional left lower quadrant tenderness but having a bowel movement makes her pain better. Uses hyoscyamine as needed but not very often. Having more constipation and taking MiraLAX a couple times a week. Does not always schedule it. States she is having a bowel movement daily but it is very small. Feels like her stools are ""slowing down"". Her nausea is good and no longer needing medications. Denies any reflux symptoms. Try stopping drinking Diet Coke because she feels that is causing increased gas. Does drink about a can a day and has been off of it for about a week. States she had labs done by her endocrinologist
Discussed doing an MRI to look at her liver but she is claustrophobic and will have to be sedated.
-- Screening colonoscopy April 10, 2012 by Dr. Shaffer and was normal.
----Had small bowel obstruction in August 2, 2013 and was felt to be due to adhesions and took a segment of small bowel (Dr. See was surgeon). Had C.diff while in the hospital and was on Flagyl.
--Labs from 2/19/2014 showed AST 73, ALT 90 AP 124 Tbil 0.3 HgA1C 7.1%
--RUQ u/s on Feb 7, 2014 showed cholelithiasis without secondary finding to suggest acute cholecystitis. Liver within normal limits. No focal liver lesion.

--Liver biopsy in April 2014 was done which showed: bx showed mild acute hepatitis with prominent eosinophils c/w drug efffect. No fibrosis and little fat. Also with bile cholestatis c/w statin... Since stopped her statin (Crestor) and Zetia and monitor LFT.
--Labs 9/15/2016 Chol 169 LDL 102 HDL 62 ALT 26 AST 24 AP 71 Tbil 0.5 TSH normal
--Ct scan abd/pelvis 7/3/2018 showed no diverticulitits. post op changes and significant stool retention. No small bowel obstruction.
--Bog 2/1/2019 was negative but baseline level is elevated. '
--Abdominal ultrasound 9/14/2020 No significant findings or abnormalities. No ascites seen. Liver was unremarkable
--Fibroscan 9/2020 results CAP 189 KPA 4.8 liver is within normal range and there is low risk for fatty liver and fibrosis

--Labs from 9/22/2020 T bili 0.4 alk phos 70 AST 34 ALT 47, hepatitis A, B and C were nonreactive, anti-smooth muscle antibody negative, ANA negative, and AMA negative, ferritin low at 10, celiac sprue antibodies negative, iron saturation 17%

--Methodist Metropolitan Hospital 12/3/2020 was seen for right hand injury and feeling constipated. Also has some abdominal pain. States Dulcolax helped with her pain. KUB 12/3/2020 normal bowel gas pattern. She had a dorsal dislocation of her second PIP joint and she had a reduction.
--Labs from 3/1/2021, T bili 0.4 and direct 0.3 alk phos 60 AST 29 ALT 25 ferritin 14 iron saturation 11%
--Labs from 8/2/2021 showed a T bili 0.5 alk phos 66 AST 39 ALT 51, ferritin 37 and iron saturation 30%
-- FibroScan November 15, 2021 CAP 346 kPa 4.6 likely fatty liver. Does not appear to have any scarring or fibrosis.
--Labs from 12/7/2021 showed a T bili of 0.5 alk phos 57 AST 24 ALT 26 her iron saturation was 24%, and ferritin was 30
--Labs from 6/6/2022 T bili 0.5 alk phos 67 AST 38 ALT 46, iron saturation 23% and ferritin low at 13.

--Colonoscopy 10/15/2022 previous surgery in the colon ileocolonic changes in the right colon with ulceration noted on anastomosis. Biopsies of the cecum showed ulceration and acute inflammation no chronic changes. 5 mm tubular adenoma removed in the transverse colon. Repeat colon 5 years
--Labs from 12/6/2022 Tbil 0.3 AP 52 AST 25 ALT 24 WBC 5.2 h/h: 13.7/43.4 plt 301 ferritin 14 iron sat 14%
--Labs 10/11/23: protein 5.8 (L), albumin 3.5 (L), tBil 0.4, AP 57, AST 23, ALT 27, wbc 4.8, hgb 13.3, PLT 290, iron 105, ferritin 46
--CT abdomen/pelvis 10/10/23: abnormal midline lower pelvis SB loops. Unclear if enteritis or ischemic SB. liver normal. No hepatic mass. No gallstone. No biliary ductal dilatation.

--CT abdomen pelvis with contrast 10/19/2023 showed large amount of colonic and rectal stool without obstruction or inflammation. No diverticulitis 3.5 cm. periampullary duodenal diverticulum Reviewed with radiology who read the first CT scan and the first non contrast CT which did look abnormal but this has totally resolved. Currently normal except for constipation
––FibroScan 4/5/2024: CAP 392, K PA 8.8– Likely fatty liver, and possible mild scarring. Consider participation and Pinnacle research for fatty liver disease.
--Stool studies from 10/1/2024 showed E. coli negative no Salmonella no Campylobacter O&P negative fecal leukocytes negative celiac negative
--Labs 10/1/2024 BMP normal WBC 5.4 H&H is 15.1/47.5 plt 381

--Northeast Baptist ER November 3, 2024 diagnosed with UTI pyelonephritis. He was started on Bactrim. Labs from November 1, 2024 showed sodium 134 potassium 4.1 chloride 97 BUN 17 creatinine 0.8 albumin 3.8 alk phos 134 AST 13 ALT 12 lipase 6 white count 12 H&H is 13.3 and 42.1 platelet count is 655 CT scan with contrast showed no dilation of the bowel or obstruction. Intermittent segments of stool-filled colon particular in the ascending descending into the proximal sigmoid colon. Transverse colon was decompressed and the rectosigmoid colon shows fluid contents. Nonobstructive bowel gas pattern. Intermittent segments of formed stools and liquid in the colon is nonspecific. No bowel wall thickening. Asymmetric enhancement of the right renal parenchymal of the mid to upper pole which may be seen in pyelonephritis
--KUB 11/6/2024 showed moderate to large colonic stool burden. Nonobstructive bowel gas

Mary Burchett is a 88 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit.   Since last visit, she notes resolution in epigastric and right upper quadrant pain. She did not complete MRI with MRCP as per recommendation, for unknown reasons. She did have MRI of lumbar spine. There are no additional GI complaints at today's visit. column1: Epigastric pain-nonspecific & improved over time. Again, further recommendations pending results of below imaging.

Dilated common bile duct-differential diagnosis and diagnostic evaluation was reviewed. These are common in the postcholecystectomy state, and also are more significantly dilated with age as well. The possibility of a distal obstruction cannot fully be excluded, but again is not likely based on the normal hepatic enzymes and atypical nature of her pain. However, it cannot fully be excluded without dedicated imaging, and after extensive discussion today, it remains her strong desire to proceed especially given lack of clarity as to etiology for her pain and described abnormality of a liver process by imaging in the past. The rationale and risks and benefits were discussed and she agrees to proceed. We will perform MRCP without contrast to better delineate.
GERD-longstanding, with episodic symptoms which are not particular problematic to her at this time. No mandate for specific therapy unless there is no clear etiology based on results above

Fatty liver/abnormal LFTs: Hx of fatty liver. mostly hepatocellular pattern with prior labs: AST 59, ALT 40. Ultrasound showed generalized fatty infiltration liver and 1 cm hypoechoic nodular area in the central aspect of the left lobe of the liver. Follow up CT liver 4 phase with steatotic liver disease without splenomegaly, no evidence of a primary hepatic neoplasm, inflow and outflow vessels to the liver are patent. Will check follow up labs.

We discussed the pathophysiology, diagnosis, and treatment of fatty liver disease. Risk factors include elevated BMI, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes but also highlighting that it is a diagnosis of exclusion. We discussed the spectrum of fatty liver and potential progression to cirrhosis as well as the potential complications of cirrhosis, but provided reassurance that this change occurs over time. I recommended abstinence from alcohol, and to pursue diet, exercise, and weight loss with a goal to lose at least 7-10% of body weight to help reverse steatosis and early fibrotic changes. We discussed the recent benefits found to be related to Mediterranean diet in the setting of fatty liver.

This is a patient we see for elevated LFTs, constipation and GERD. Has family history with her maternal grandmother having colon cancer but no first degree relative. Dad had pancreatic cancer but no other family member. Last seen may 2025 by me.

GERD managed with Omeprazole 40 mg in the morning with Famotidine 40 mg at bedtime. Constipation managed with taking magnesium daily and MiraLAX a couple times a week and having a bowel movement daily.

Has been having elevated liver enzymes and her rheumatologist, Dr. Jose Roldan was considering starting her on methotrexate but concerned about her history of elevated LFTs. They did lower her Plaquenil since she lost weight but still having increased symptoms of her joint pain. Noted labs November 8, 2024 showed ALT of 254, AST of 107, alk phos of 101. MR elastography April 30, 2024 was normal. Still on Ozempic for her A1c (did briefly stop taking it at one point).

Was initially referred to see us in June 2012 when her labs from April 2012 showed an ALT of 102, AST 41. Labs June 2012 with ALT 57, AST 46.  Had a Liver biopsy 12/18/2012 showed mild portal triaditis with occasional eosinophils; mild increased iron deposits; fibrosis absent. column1: 62 year old female here in follow up for elevated LFTs.  Also with GERD and bloating.

LFTs have been elevated since at least 2012 and she's had serological workup that was negative, and liver bx 12/18/2012 showed mild portal triaditis with occasional eosinophils; mild increased iron deposits; fibrosis absent. Serological workup June 2012 with ANA, ASMA and AMA negative, alpha 1 antitrypsin normal at 123, ceruloplasmin normal 34, iron 83 with 21% sat, ferritin 23, LK M1 antibody normal, hepatitis B and hepatitis C negative.  November 2012 had negative celiac screening panel.   CMV IgM and IgG antibodies and PCR negative July 2014. GGT normal March 2017.   Noted she did not start on Plaquenil until 2019.  Only medication that she was on in 2012 and still on is Topamax and Synthroid.  Topamax has less than 1% chance of causing elevated LFTs and considered class C for liver tox, so very unlikely to be the culprit.

MR elastography April 30, 2024 was normal. We did refer her to Methodise Liver Transplant for second opinion and they did blood work with serological test February 2025 negative.  They did recommended MRCP with secretin which she has not heard back about scheduling that yet. She was supposed to see them in May but they cancelled her appt and rescheduled for August and then recently cancelled her appt again and have not rescheduled her yet.   Encouraged her to contact them next week if she has not heard from them by then.  Recent LFTs from May with AST 67, ALT 160.  Would like MSTH input if they think she needs repeat liver bx or not, she is also still waiting to hear back about scheduling the MRCP with secretin.
GERD -- is managed with  Omeprazole 40mg and Famotidine 40mg. Is on Ozempic which can worsen reflux.  May use OTC Gaviscon as needed.

Constipation --was having small, hard pellet stools. Advised to continue Benefiber daily and to increase her Miralax from 1/2 capful to 1 capful daily. Noted Ozempic can worsen constipation.Is presently doing better with Miralax and Benefiber.

Bloating -- having some increased bloating/gas, seems mostly related to mealtime.  D/w patient Low FODMAP diet and if that does not improve her symptoms then would recommend H+ breath test for SIBO evaluation and labs to screen for celiac since its been 13 years since last.

column2: --please be sure to get back in touch with Methodist Liver Transplant center, if you are unable to see them back then let us know and we can do referral to Texas Liver Institute

column1: --Low FODMAP diet handout. If bloating does not improve then would look into doing blood work to screen for celiac disease (autoimmune allergy to gluten) and then also breath test for SIBO (small intestinal bacterial overgrowth)"

Nancy Walker is a 66 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit.

Patient was last seen September 2022 for left lower quadrant abdominal pain. At that time she reported 2 months of intermittent left lower quadrant pain that starts off gradually and ends up in excruciating pain that last 2 to 3 minutes and then stops. Reported 25 pounds of unintentional weight loss. Noted her GERD was under good control with Nexium 20 mg in the morning. Reported 1 bowel movement per week and stated this is her normal baseline. Reported that fiber supplements worsen her symptoms. Underwent EGD/colonoscopy 10/27/2022: EGD with findings of localized irregular margins of erythema in the GE junction, 8 cm hiatal hernia noted, gastritis with biopsy negative for H. pylori, normal duodenum. Colon with mild diverticulosis throughout the colon, 8 mm SSA polyp in the ascending colon, internal hemorrhoids.

Patient called our office in August reporting abdominal pain and diarrhea as well as vomiting. She had gone to the ER and was diagnosed with colitis on CT scan. Reviewed her outside records. Was seen at North Central Baptist ER 8/18/2025 symptoms occurred after eating a fast food salad. CT abdomen pelvis with contrast shows a moderate size hiatal hernia with reflux of the fluid in the esophagus. Simple appearing hepatic cysts diffusely thickened hyperemic colonic and rectal mucosa consistent with diffuse proctocolitis. Was given Bentyl and Zofran. Labs showed a white count of 5.8 H&H is 15.1 and 43 platelet count is 245 albumin 4.3 alk phos 66 AST 10 ALT 7.

We did offer stool studies but patient declined, stating diarrhea had subsided.  We did have great difficulty getting in touch with patient as our calls to her would go straight to her voice mail and we would leave a message to call us back but she stated she never received the missed calls or voicemails.  We told her we felt she likely has a spam blocker on her phone that may be blocking calls from phone numbers that she does not have saved in her contacts.  She later saved our office phone number to her contacts and then was able to start receiving our phone calls.
Noted, had some difficulty obtaining history from patient, unable to give clear answers to my specific questions.

Currently, patient reports that the ER note neglected to note that she was in excruciating abdominal pain for 4 days and that she was having explosive diarrhea and uncontrollable. Said had waited 4 days before going to the ER because she thought she would eventually get better.  Says they had a hard time getting an IV line in her in the ER because she was so dehydrated, despite multiple attemps by various staff. Says eventually the last person pierced through her vein and has a large bruise and swelling still and did see her PCP for this yesterday. She did take the Bentyl and Zofran, says it helped some.  Says eating bland food and even drinking water causes cramping, but they are less excruciating than before.  Says had 1 BM with a stool that had a white streak and had some stools with mucus.  Has not seen any further stools with white in them.  Reports sensation she needs to have a BM but does not pass anything.  Reports bloating.  Reports dull nausea and uncomfortable feeling below her belly button and across her abdomen. Reports 2 stools that were ""like balls"" that she had yesterday and the day before. Says the stools were hard firm and dry and required effort to get them out. Says baseline BM is constipation and does not typically have a daily BM.   Says a month or so ago had ""something like this"" but the pain was not as intense and had seen her PCP and by the time she got to her PCP the pain was pretty much gone, had only lasted about 2 days.
Says had brain injury in 2011 and uses a cane to help get around

--Colonoscopy 7/16/2012 showed 10 cm of acute proctitis and biopsy showed just acute erosive proctitis but did not look chronic. Also had a few diverticuli but no polyps. Reviewed with pathologist and looks acute process. Bx with mild acute erosive proctitis.

--EGD March 5, 2013 showed a 5 cm hiatal hernia was noted (32-37 cm). At the GEJ was a shallow 8 mm ulceration c/w ulcerative esophagitis. No stricture or narrowing was noted in the esophagus however the esophagus appeared torturous. Gastric erythema was seen in the gastric body and antrum. Biopsies were negative for Helicobacter pylori. A lap band was noted in the fundus of the stomach.

--EGD/colonoscopy 10/27/2022: EGD with findings of localized irregular margins of erythema in the GE junction, 8 cm hiatal hernia noted, gastritis with biopsy negative for H. pylori, normal duodenum. Colon with mild diverticulosis throughout the colon, 8 mm SSA polyp in the ascending colon, internal hemorrhoids.

--CT abdomen pelvis with contrast 8/18/2025: shows a moderate size hiatal hernia with reflux of the fluid in the esophagus. Simple appearing hepatic cysts diffusely thickened hyperemic colonic and rectal mucosa consistent with diffuse proctocolitis.

column1: 66-year-old female presents via televisit in follow-up from an ER visit she had 8/18/2025 at North Central Baptist for abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting and diarrhea. Her CT scan showed diffusely thickened hyperemic colonic and rectal mucosa consistent with diffuse proctocolitis. Her symptoms have been present for 4 days at the time of her ER presentation. She was sent home with prescription for Bentyl and Zofran. She notes some improvement in her symptoms but still overall does not feel back to normal and is seeing mucus in her stools and still with dull abdominal pain and bloating. Her last colonoscopy was in October 2022 with an 8 mm SSA polyp in the ascending colon.

Given that she is still having symptoms we will proceed with a colonoscopy to evaluate for any evidence of an inflammatory bowel disease or alternative etiology. Patient does not want to complete stool studies at this time. Will prescribe dicyclomine 10 mg every 4-6 hours as needed for her abdominal cramping. Cautioned her on side effect of constipation. She will need to hold her Mounjaro prior to her colonoscopy. She can continue on a soft and bland diet for now. She can also try over-the-counter Prevacid for her heartburn since she cannot find Nexium tablets anymore.

column1: Issac is a pleasant 40 year old male with PMH including anxiety who presents via telemedicine follow up of his reflux. We reviewed his good response to Voquezna initially though after missing this for a little over a week his symptoms did recur and worsen. Despite resuming his Voquezna at 10 mg he does continue with symptoms particularly with pyrosis, regurgitation, and bloating. I did recommend he add on famotidine to his Voquezna dose and proceed with the gastric emptying scan previously ordered due to retained fluid in his stomach on his EGD. He did admit that he was having some difficulties with affording this earlier in the year. So, we will go ahead and have him try a gastroparesis friendly diet in the interim with a handout provided. I do suspect there may be an anxiety component as well worsening his symptoms leading to the ""taking his breath away"", etc. Also, he has been evaluated by cardiology with a benign stress test reportedly.

column1: Andrea Moore is a 71 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit.   She presents for follow-up visit to discuss recent bout of left lower quadrant pain. She is concerned that she may have had a recurrent diverticulitis flare. She did undergo CT scan with PCP recently which showed evidence of mild focal fat stranding in the diverticula in the mid to proximal transverse colon however cannot exclude mild diverticulitis. Since undergoing the CT scan, she notes near resolution in left lower quadrant discomfort. She reports left lower quadrant pain does occur intermittently and she describes a throbbing pain.. She did undergo sigmoidectomy in 2024 given history of chronic smoldering diverticulitis. Again, currently she reports resolution in symptoms which led to the CT scan. She occasionally experiences constipation, but reports this is mild. There is no hematochezia or melena. She denies any fevers, nausea, vomiting.
CT scan 2025: mild focal fat stranding iin the diverticula mid to proximal transverse colon, can not exclude mild diverticulitis

She recently hospitalized for complicated diverticulitis, which was identified based upon a CT scan performed in the presence of mild abdominal cramping. She denied fevers preceding this and had not been on steroids or other immunosuppressive agents. She was hospitalized for percutaneous drainage and administration of IV antibiotics and has had prompt and near complete resolution of symptoms.

GERD: Seems to be well-controlled PPI therapy. I do recommend titration to lowest therapeutic dose.
Hepatic steatosis noted on recent CT scan: Recommend fibroscan to delineate the degree of steatosis and fibrosis.

column1: Unintentional weight loss of 10% body weight within 6 months
58F with HTN, depression, IDDM, h/o cholecystectomy, h/o hysterectomy presenting for follow up:
#LUQ abdominal/flank pain with radiation to pelvis

Presentation 7/2025: Patient reports severe abdominal bloating, pain, nausea, vomiting, constipation, and diarrhea for the past two months. The symptoms began suddenly without any known trigger. The pain was predominantly on the right side and the entire abdomen was tender and sore. The patient reported episodes of constipation lasting seven to ten days, interspersed with diarrhea. Despite the use of Miralax, Milk of Magnesia, and stool softeners, the patient continued to struggle with bowel movements, which were infrequent and involved passing thin stools. The patient visited the emergency room four times, where CT scans indicated constipation. Previous medical advice included the use of daily Miralax leading up to a planned colonoscopy. The patient also expressed concern about potential endometriosis affecting the bowel, especially since a history of early-stage endometriosis was noted during a prior hysterectomy.

OV 9/2025: Differential includes intussusception, autoimmune disease, systemic pathology such as vasculitis/lupus, primary gastric disorder such as PUD. EGD indicated for unintentional weight loss >10% TBWL in 6 months, early satiety, bloating. Rest of workup below.

column1: Heriberto Reynolds is a 60 year old male who is seen today for a annual visit for management of GERD. He continues taking pantoprazole 40 mg daily without complaints. There is no dysphagia, odynophagia, unintentional weight loss. Overall, this dose seems to manage reflux symptoms, there is occasional exacerbations, typically related to dietary indiscretion. But again, there have been no alarm symptoms over time. He has history of gastric sleeve in 2012 for which she does take multivitamin 4. There is no change in bowel habits, hematochezia, melena. Last EGD was from 2015 and showed evidence of class B esophagitis, 4 cm hiatal hernia. Last colonoscopy was in 2021, detailed below.

He was previously hospitalized briefly while traveling in Boston, because of low back and chest discomfort. Workup showed a fluid-filled esophagus, with hiatal hernia, and he subsequently had laboratory workup that was otherwise unremarkable and was referred back for evaluation. Following this the endoscopy, as noted below, showed evidence of grade B esophagitis and a 4 cm hiatal hernia, which was not present several years ago. After continued use of Protonix, once daily, his symptoms responded entirely
EGD 2012-performed because of suggestion of a previous gastric polyp, not identified, but there was evidence of mild peptic esophagitis with H. pylori negative gastropathy
Barium swallow 6/2017-normal esophagus with normal peristalsis, small sliding hiatal hernia, similar in appearance to previous study, with several episodes of small-volume spontaneous reflux
EGD 11/2015-Los Angeles grade B erosive esophagitis, 4 cm hiatal hernia, otherwise normal post-sleeve gastrectomy endoscopy

Records from hospitalization in Boston 11/2015-normal chemistries, normal hepatic profile, alcohol and phosphatase 136, normal cardiac enzymes, normal CBC with hematocrit 43.1 and MCV 87, CT showing hiatal hernia with fluid-filled esophagus but no other acute abnormality.

column1: GERD with history of Class B Esophagitis, 4 cm hiatal hernia: We again discussed the pathophysiology, natural history, and treatments of hiatal hernias. The cornerstone of therapy for those with mild to moderate symptoms remains conservative, with dietary modification, weight loss, and PPI therapy, titrating to lowest therapeutic dose. Surgery may be considered for large hernias or those which do not respond to conservative measures. In this case, he is stable on current dose and therefore see no reason to make any changes. He may add in h2 antagonist or alginate as needed for breakthrough symptoms.

History of Gastrectomy: Again encouraged a bariatric multivitamin. Routine laboratory testing to assess for deficiencies of vitamins, B12, folic acid, iron, vitamin D, calcium, fat-soluble vitamins, zinc, and copper, should be performed annually. Will order labs today.

If he does not take this, he will experience heartburn. He has been told he has fatty liver in the past but has not had a recent FibroScan.
